If you have the cold water on and the pressure is fairly low, then you turn the hot water on and the pressure goes up, but the water is still cold for awhile.

The reason:

Water is almost always in pipes. The hot water in the hot water pipe has cooled over time and become room temp. So, when you turn the hot water valve you open a pipe filled with water, but it's cold. After that water has moved through the pipes it is replaced (obviously) with the water from your water heater.

It's just a naming convention that early physicists made a mistake that we haven't corrected yet. It's because magnetic fields always point to the south pole of a magnet, measured using a compass. The compass was introduced to Europe by the time they had established directions on maps, and people just got the directions mixed up by not knowing enough of the science behind compasses. The naming convention went unchanged, as many people already called it the North Pole.

Since you were talking about different "North Poles" on the Earth, it would have been useful to talk about "Grid North Pole", which is the location on the Earth where the geographic maps use as the reference point.  Because maps were made before the "geographic north pole" was established, it only got a rough approximation and is now different.  Deviation is also listed on any high quality map as well.
